results.title: The Story of time
results.creator_credit: Jan Coolen, Robert Leffingwell and Signal Films
results.brief_description: Part animated film dramatising man’s attempts over the centuries to measure time. Sun worshippers measured the hours by the shades of obelisk and sun-dial; the first clocks were worked by the elements - such as the sand glass, the Chinese fire clock, and the Persian water clock. The mechanical clocks and pocket watches of the last two centuries are symbolised by a ballet of pendulums, leading to the precision instruments that are the clocks and watches of the present day, measuring time with great accuracy.

results.title: The Story of the weeping camel = Die Geschichte vom weinenden kamel
results.creator_credit: Luigi Falorni, Byambasuren Davaa, Tobias Siebert, Film Munchen and Hochschule fur Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Set in the Gobi Desert, Southern Mongolia, this narrative-style documentary explains a wonderful custom that could be used as an allegory for motherhood in the modern world. Made by two student filmmakers, they travel to Mongolia to meet a family of three generations living a simple nomadic lifestyle. During the spring, one of the family’s camels has a difficult delivery, giving birth to a rare white colt but she then rejects the youngster. Two family members set off to fetch a musician who plays a violin-like stringed instrument. The musician and a female family member perform a simple ritual that will re-unite the mother camel with her young. Striking landscape vistas and moving insight into the nomadic family life are captured by Luigi Falorni’s cinematography in this poignant representation of folklore and traditional storytelling. Nominated in the 2004 Academy Awards for Best Documentary (feature length).

results.title: The Story of the Timna copper miner
results.brief_description: King Solomon’s mines were rediscovered by geologists, who found the old copper deposits. Laboratory research led to the development of suitable production methods in these difficult conditions of burning heat. Ore is blasted, treated with sulphuric acid in order to separate the copper.
results.title_for_label: The Story of the Timna copper miner

results.title: The Story of the St Lawrence Seaway
results.brief_description: This film describes the Seaway project from conception to completion, from the early fur trade to June, 1959, when Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II and President Dwight D. Eisenhower declared the Seaway open. Animated drawings show the profile of the waterway.

results.title: The Story of the Spitfire
results.creator_credit: Dave Flitton, David McWhinnie, Pegasus and Classic Pictures Entertainment
results.brief_description: The Supermarine Spitfire, an aeroplane that was the ultimate symbol of defiance in the battle of Britain during World War 2, helped reverse the Allied fortunes. With a Rolls Royce engine and dual cannon/machinegun armament, it was fast and manoeuvrable, at the cutting edge of RAF fighting designs and was a key component in the struggle against Hitler’s elite force, the Luftwaffe. When Hitler started amassing a formidable aerial army, the British started to panic about possible motives and the prospect of another war, in which for the first time, the principal battles would be fought in the air. As a result, more than 23,000 Spitfires were built and it was the only Allied fighter to remain in production throughout the duration of the war. The plane fulfilled diverse roles - tactical fighter-bomber, fast interceptor and high and low level reconnaissance missions. This documentary combines dramatic archival film, from the 1930s and 40s, of the Spitfire in action, with colour footage of surviving models in flight. Aeroplane enthusiasts, and particularly those interested in war planes, should enjoy the historical visuals and informative narrative on this disc.

results.title: The Story of the Southern Cross: an Australian Aboriginal legend
results.creator_credit: Thelma Dufton, Pilgrim Films and Concept Films of Australia
results.brief_description: Using drawings, tells the story of the origin of the Southern Cross. Adapted from an Aboriginal legend by Marcia Hatfield. Narration by Ron Haddrick.

results.title: The Story of the soil
results.creator_credit: Coronet Instructional Films and Morrow Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the soil from the beginning of earth. How human interference with the partnership between the soil and vegetation has reduced many areas to desolation. Emphasises the need to restore nature’s harmony between climate, soil, plants, animals, and humans.

results.title: The Story of the Snowy Scheme
results.creator_credit: H Malcolm and Snowy Mountains Authority
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Scheme. Ultimately the Scheme will double Australia’s present power output and will provide ample irrigation water each year. Excavatgions are in progress for miles of tunnel which will divert the waters of the Snowy into the Murray, Murrumbidgee and Tumut Rivers. Maps and diagrams as well as photographs show what has been achieved. The Munyong Power Station was officially opened by the Prime Minister in 1955. The completed Guthega Dam supplies this station with water.

results.title: The Story of the Olympics
results.creator_credit: Derek Conrad and Conrad Television Associates
results.brief_description: This video will delight anyone with a love of sport or a general interest in the history of one of the world’s greatest sporting events. From as early as the first Olympic marathon which was won, appropriately enough by a Greek water-carrier, to as recent as the Seoul 1988, when the return of the Russians pushed the United States into third place and the drugs issue made headlines a Ben Johnson was stripped of his medal, you can relive the triumph and the heartache that have combined to make the Olympics the inspiration that they are today.

results.title: The Story of the letter post
results.creator_credit: David Morphet, Oswald Skilbeck and General Post Office
results.brief_description: this film recounts the gradual development of the British mail service from the fifteenth century, reconstructed with period costumes, museum pieces, and old stamps. Early use of messengers and Henry VIII’s service expanded for public use by Charles I; 1660 Act of Parliament; Ralph Allan’s reforms; the Industrial Revolution; improved roads and the mail coach; Rowland Hill’s penny post and modern mechanical methods.
